_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Accidental Toxic Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

At the City of Franklin Wastewater Treatment Plant, chlorine is used as a disinfectant in the Chlorine Contact Basin.  The Cholrine is injected via water pressure to the head of the Chlorine Contact Basin.  We have only one tank (1 Ton Cylinder) hooked up to the process feeding approximately 20 lbs./day.  Chemical safety is of the utmost importance to this facility.  Safety measures are in use involving the handlilng and usage of chlorine and trying to comply with all state and federal laws and regulations.  Employees are trained on Chemical Safety an the proper procedures to follow for change-outs, precautionary measures, use of Scott Air Paks and other safety devices at their disposal.  An Emergency Response Plan is in place and coordinated with the Local Emergency Planning Service in the event of an accidental release.

Regulated Substances Handled

The Franklin Wastewater Treatment Plant has not had any accidents at this facility during the "Five Year History".  It still holds true today that to my knowledge, there has never been an accidental release of chlorine at this facility since its construction in 1984.

Emergency Response Plan

The Emergency Response Plan for the Wastewater Treatment Plant is based on the Commonwealth of Kentucky's Division of Emergency Management's "Tab Q-7".  This plan is incorporated into the county's Emergency Response Plan for Simpson County by the LEPC.  This plan is periodically reviewed by the LEPC and updated by individual facilities.

Planned Safety Improvements

We continue to be very safety oriented and will continue to strive to improve safety measures at this facility.  The Franklin Wastewater Treatment Plant will continue to use safety audits, inspections, and safety meetings to focus on improving our operating procedures regarding the use of chlorine.

Included in the ERP are truck routes used by the chlorine vendors that would be used in transporting C

hlorine to this facility.  Access to any and all areas of this facility are restricted to authorized personnel only and authorized contractors.  An electronic gate at the entrance of this facility will be installed after the new budget is approved beginning July 1st, 2006.  Qualified personnel are on hand during loading and off-loading of Chlorine Cylinders.  The room used to house the Chlorine is separated by a solid brick wall that extends all the way to the top of the building, completely made of brick with a concrete floor.  Alarm systems are in place in the storage area plus additional alarms and analyzers located in the Administrative Building.

Worst Case Scenario

In a worst case scenario, chlorine gas would be released from the building using the model that was indicated under the "Worst Case Scenario" sefction of this RMP.  The total amound of chlorine that could be released under this secenario woulb be 2000 lbs.  We would certainly hope that through administrative controls, mitigation measures and participation with LEP in "mock" disasters that we would be prepared for such an accidental release.

Five Year Accident History
